name: Command History & Shortcuts
description: Learn how to use command history and keyboard shortcuts effectively

flashcards.question: How do you run the last command that started with "ls"?
flashcards.example:
$ ls -l /etc
... (output of the ls command)
$ pwd
/etc
$ !ls
ls -l /etc
... (executes ls -l /etc again)

flashcards.question: How do you re-run the 26th command in the history list?
flashcards.example:
$ history
...
  26  ping google.com
...
$ !26
ping google.com
... (executes the ping command)

flashcards.question: What keyboard shortcut moves the cursor to the beginning of the command line?
flashcards.example: If you're typing a command and want to move the cursor to the start, press Ctrl+A.

flashcards.question: What keyboard shortcut moves the cursor to the end of the command line?
flashcards.example: While editing a command, press Ctrl+E to move the cursor to the end.

flashcards.question: What shortcut clears all text from the cursor to the beginning of the command line?
flashcards.example: Position the cursor where you want to start clearing, then press Ctrl+U.

flashcards.question: What shortcut clears all text from the cursor to the end of the command line?
flashcards.example: Place the cursor at the starting point, press Ctrl+K to delete to the end.

flashcards.question: What shortcut moves the cursor to the beginning of the previous word?
flashcards.example: While typing, press Alt+B to move back one word.

flashcards.question: What shortcut moves the cursor to the end of the next word?
flashcards.example: Press Alt+F to move forward one word.

flashcards.question: What shortcut searches your command history for a specific pattern?
flashcards.example:
Press Ctrl+R, then start typing the pattern to search.
The terminal will display the matching command.

flashcards.question: How do you execute multiple commands on a single line?
flashcards.answer: Separate the commands with a semicolon ;.
flashcards.example:
$ cd /var/log; ls; pwd
Changes directory to /var/log
Lists files in /var/log
Displays the current directory
